abstract: Responding to regulators in Europe, Google argues that the Internet Protocol address associated with a computer shouldn’t be protected as personal information. But I.P. addresses can be used, along with other information, to track what people do online.
snippet: Responding to regulators in Europe, Google argues that the Internet Protocol address associated with a computer shouldn’t be protected as personal information. But I.P. addresses can be used, along with other information, to track what people do o...
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: Two Google officials, Matt Cutts, a top search engineer, and Peter Fleischer, Google’s global privacy counsel, wrote comments below reacting to this post. I wrote some thoughts responding to their comments in another post here.

headline.main: Google Says I.P. Addresses Aren’t Personal
